date      : Tue, 31 Dec 2019 19:06:34 -0600
===================================================================
Body (clean, unformatted):

*Today’s Verse:*

*Zacchaeus stood and said to the Lord; behold Lord,*

*half of my goods I give to the poor; and if I have*

*taken any thing from any man by false accusation,*

*I will restore to him fourfold. *(Lk 19:10)

(read Lk. 19:1-10)



*Today’s Reflection:*

Everyone knew that tax collectors were becoming rich

by gouging their fellow Jews. No wonder the people

muttered when Jesus went home with Zacchaeus, the

tax collector. But despite the fact that Zacchaeus was

both a cheater and a turn coat, Jesus loved him, and

in response the tax collector was converted. In every

society, certain groups of people are considered

“untouchable” because of their political views, their

immoral behavior, or their life style.

*Jesus loves them and they need to hear the Good *

*News.*

Remember the words we pray, “forgive us our trespasses *as we* forgive
those who trespass against us.



Remember too Mt. 7:1 “Judge not that you be not judged.”

*Pastor Al*

Remember too Matthew 7:1 “Judge not that you be not judged.”

Like Zacchaeus, we recognize that we are all sinners in need of Your grace and forgiveness. Help us to follow the example of Christ, who loved the unlovable and welcomed the outcast. May we extend Your compassion to all, remembering that we too have been forgiven much. In Your Son's name, we pray. Amen.

subject   : Subject: SEEKING WISE COUNSEL (1-2-2020)
from      : Pastor Sather <pastor.sather5@gmail.com>
to        : undisclosed-recipients:;
date      : Wed, 1 Jan 2020 19:01:39 -0600
===================================================================
Body (clean, unformatted):

*Today’s Verse:*

*Trust in the Lord with all your heart and lean not on your own
understanding; in all your ways submit to *

*Him, and He will make your paths straight. *(Pro. 3:5-6)



*Today’s Reflections:*

When we have an important decision to make, we sometimes think we can not
even trust God. In my experience it is because I have not had the patience
to wait on God. (Shame on me!) At those times I have forgotten that God
knows what is best for me. I have found through the years that He is a
better judge of

what I need. At the same time we should not omit

careful thinking or belittle our God-given ability to reason; but we should
not trust our own ideas to the exclusion of wise counselors and what the
Bible has

to say. *Let’s make God a vital part of everything *

*we do, then He will guide us, because we will be working to accomplish His
purpose.*

* Pastor Al*

Let’s make God a vital part of everything we do, then He will guide us, because we will be working to accomplish His purpose.

prayer: Heavenly Father, we confess that we often struggle to trust in Your perfect plan and timing, forgetting that You know what is best for us. Forgive us for the impatience that leads us to rely on our own limited understanding instead of seeking Your guidance. Help us to wait patiently and quietly before You, trusting in Your wisdom and leading, that we may walk in the path You have set before us. May we make You the center of all we do, that You may direct our steps according to Your purpose. Amen.

*Today’ Verse:*

*We know that we have come to know Him if we keep His commandments…*

*But if anyone obeys His Word, love for God is truly made complete to t
him. *(I Jn. 2:3, 5)



*Today’s Reflection:*

The question that has been asked more than once is; “How can we know for
sure that we belong to Christ?” This passage gives two ways to know; if
you *do* what Christ says, and *live *as Christ wants. What does Christ
tell us to do? John answers in (3:23) “Believe in the name of His Son,
Jesus Christ *and* love one another.” True Christian faith results in a
loving behavior; that is why John says that, *the way we act can give us
the assurance that we belong to Christ. *

* Pastor Al*

May our lives be a testament to the faith we profess, that we may have the assurance of belonging to You. Guide us, Lord, to love one another as You have loved us. In Jesus' name, Amen.

*Today’s Verse:*

*If the Son therefore make you free, you shall be *

*free indeed. *(Jn. 8:36)



*Today’s Reflection:*

Not one negative habit or situation is too hard for Jesus to repair or
remove from our life. Do you struggle with a habit that hinders your
personal advancement? Pray today for a transformed mind in this new year— *and
ask Jesus to reveal His exit plan for your release.*

* Pastor Al*

Lord, reveal Your exit plan for our release, that we may walk in the freedom You have promised through Your Son, Jesus Christ. Amen.

*Today’s Verse:*

*And Jesus said to him, “Today salvation has come *

*to this house, **since he also is a son of Abraham. *

*For the Son of Man came to **seek and to save the *

*lost.” *(Lk. 19:9-10)

*Today’s Reflection:*

I am so grateful that Jesus cared about me enough to save me. He willingly
gave His life for mine. And it

does not matter what anyone else thinks. Sometimes

I get so discouraged about things in my life or choices I’ve made that I
don’t feel worthy of anything. But

then I remember that Paul said in Phil. 1:6 that I should be confident in
the knowledge that Jesus will complete the work that He has started in me.

*We all face moments when we feel unworthy. *

*Today, meditate on Phil. 1:6 and remember *

*that Jesus isn’t finished with you! You are *

*worthy in His eyes.*

* Pastor Al *

Though we often feel unworthy, we are grateful that You have started a good work in us and will faithfully complete it. Help us to trust in Your unwavering love and the transformative power of Your Spirit, even when we face discouragement. May we find our worth in You alone. Amen.

*Today’s Verse:*

*And a voice from heaven said, “This is My son, *

*whom I love; **with Him I am well pleased.” *

(Mt. 3:17)

*Today’s Reflection:*

The heavens opened as the Holy Spirit of God

descended like a dove upon Jesus. Then God spoke

of our Lord, claiming Him and encouraging Him

with words of love. I can’t imagine a more

beautiful scene of power and hope. But in the

very next verse, Jesus was led by the Spirit into

the desert to be tempted by the devil. It’s as if a

giant pendulum swung from the best time possible

to a great trial.Looking back on times you’ve found

yourself head-to-head with temptation, how did

God prepare you before those challenges? Rest

easy, knowing that as He did for Jesus, Our Father

will lead you through.

*Pastor Al*

beautiful scene of power and hope. But in the very next verse, Jesus was led by the Spirit into the desert to be tempted by the devil. Rest easy, knowing that as He did for Jesus, Our Father will lead you through.
original_verse_text: And a voice from heaven said, "This is My son, whom I love; with Him I am well pleased."
prayer: Heavenly Father, we give You thanks for the beautiful scene of Your Son's baptism, where You proclaimed Your love and affirmed His identity. Even as Jesus faced trials in the desert, You were with Him, and we trust that You will also guide us through the temptations and challenges we face. Help us to find strength and hope in Your presence, knowing that in this world we will have trouble, but that You have overcome the world. Amen.

*Verse:*

Paul says, *put to death your members which are *

*on the **earth: fornication, uncleanness, passion, *

*evil desire, and **covetousness, which is idolatry. *

(Col. 3:5)



*Today’s Reflection:*

As believers we should consider ourselves dead

and unresponsive to sexual immorality, impurity,

lust, shameful desires, and greed. We must make

a conscious daily decision to remove anything that supports or feeds these
desires and to rely on the

Holy Spirit’s power.

*Let us pray for the Holy Spirit’s power to help *

*us **discard our sinful attitudes and behaviors.*

* Pastor Al *
original_reflection_text:
As believers we should consider ourselves dead and unresponsive to sexual immorality, impurity, lust, shameful desires, and greed. We must make a conscious daily decision to remove anything that supports or feeds these desires and to rely on the Holy Spirit’s power.
Let us pray for the Holy Spirit’s power to help us discard our sinful attitudes and behaviors.

Paul says, put to death your members which are  on the earth:
fornication, uncleanness, passion,  evil desire, and covetousness, which is idolatry.
prayer: Heavenly Father, we come before You, acknowledging the sinful desires that so often seek to control our hearts and minds. Grant us the strength and wisdom to put to death the deeds of the flesh, as Your word instructs us in Romans 8:13. Empower us by Your Holy Spirit to resist the temptations of sexual immorality, impurity, and greed. May we daily choose to walk in the newness of life, casting off the old self and clothing ourselves in the righteousness of Christ. We surrender our lives to You, Lord, that we may live for Your glory. Amen.

subject   : Subject: HOW TO FIND A TRUE REWARD (1-08-2020)

*Today’s Verse:*

*He who finds his life will lose it, and he who *

*loses his **life for my sake will find it. *(Mt. 10:39)



*Today’s Reflection:*

This verse is a positive and negative statement

of the same truth. Clinging to this life may cause

us to forfeit the best from Christ in this world

and in the next. The more we love this world’s rewards such as (leisure,
power, popularity,

financial security), the more we will discover

how empty they really are. The best way to enjoy life, therefore, is to loosen
our greedy grasp on earthly rewards so that we can be free to follow
Christ. *In doing so we will inherit **eternal life *

*and begin at once to experience the benefits*

*of following Christ.*

* Pastor Al.*
original_reflection_text:
This verse is a positive and negative statement of the same truth.
Clinging to this life may cause us to forfeit the best from Christ in this world and in the next. The more we love this world’s rewards such as (leisure, power, popularity,
financial security), the more we will discover how empty they really are. The best way to enjoy life, therefore, is to loosen our greedy grasp on earthly rewards so that we can be free to follow Christ. In doing so we will inherit eternal life and begin at once to experience the benefits of following Christ.
original_subject: HOW TO FIND A TRUE REWARD
original_verse_text: He who finds his life will lose it, and he who  loses his life for my sake will find it.
prayer: Heavenly Father, we come before You, humbled by the truth that clinging to this world's rewards may cause us to forfeit the best from Christ. Help us to loosen our greedy grasp on earthly pleasures, that we may be free to follow You wholeheartedly. May we find true joy and fulfillment in the eternal life You offer, and begin to experience the blessings of walking in Your ways. Lord, guide us to value Your kingdom above all else. Amen.

This verse is a positive and negative statement of the same truth.
Clinging to this life may cause us to forfeit the best from Christ in this world and in the next. The more we love this world’s rewards such as (leisure, power, popularity,
financial security), the more we will discover how empty they really are. The best way to enjoy life, therefore, is to loosen our greedy grasp on earthly rewards so that we can be free to follow Christ. In doing so we will inherit eternal life and begin at once to experience the benefits of following Christ.

*Today’s Verse:*

*Jesus turned and saw her. “Take heart, daughter.” *

*He said,**“your faith has healed you,* and the woman

was healed at that moment. (Mt. 9:22)

*Today’s Reflection:*

Sometimes no amount of treatments or therapies can

help us as much as the promise of heaven and the hope we receive through
Jesus. A whole world of light and

life awaits us, beyond what we can see. When earthy forms of medicine fail,
we can turn to the Great Physician for help. He’ll never leave or
disappoint you.

*We only need to trust Jesus and **be patient.*

* Pastor Al*

*Today's Verse:*
*For in Him we live and move and exist * [*that is, in Him we*
*actually have our being*]. (Acts 17:28)

*Today's Reflection: *
Not only does He give us life, but according to (Gal. 2:20)
Jesus lives in us. The way to live while still here on earth
is by trusting, moment by moment, the Son of God who
loves us and gave Himself for us. So as long as Jesus
allows our heart to keep beating, we need to allow His
love to fill us to the brim, so we can love Him back and
extend that love to others. *Thank God that you are alive!*
*And remember that "In Him we live and move."*
* Pastor Al*

So as long as Jesus allows our heart to keep beating, we need to allow His love to fill us to the brim, so we can love Him back and extend that love to others. Thank God that you are alive! And remember that "In Him we live and move."

prayer: Heavenly Father, we come before You with grateful hearts, for in You we live and move and have our being. We thank You for the gift of life, and for the indwelling presence of Your Son, Jesus, who lives within us. Help us to trust in Him moment by moment, that His love may fill us and overflow to those around us. May we always remember that our true life is hidden with Christ in You. Amen.

And remember that "In Him we live and move."

*TODAY'S VERSE:*
Jesus said to Peter and Andrew, "Follow me and I will
make you fishers of man." (Mt. 4:19)

*Today's Reflection:*
Following in the footsteps of Jesus doesn't involve a
check list. True discipleship requires interacting with
Him constantly: remembering His teaching, listening
for His direction, opening our eyes to where He is at
work in our home and community.
*Remember, as Jesus meets us where we are, He*
*shows us new ways to apply those truths as we*
*follow Him.*

* Pastor Al*

Remember, as Jesus meets us where we are, He shows us new ways to apply those truths as we follow Him.
original_verse_text: Jesus said to Peter and Andrew, "Follow me and I will make you fishers of man."
prayer: Heavenly Father, we come before You, seeking to follow in the footsteps of Your Son, Jesus. Help us to constantly interact with Him, remembering His teachings, listening for Your direction, and opening our eyes to see where You are at work in our lives. As we surrender our lives to You, may we find new ways to apply Your truth and walk in obedience, even as You meet us where we are. Guide us, Lord, that we may faithfully follow You. Amen.
reflection: Following in the footsteps of Jesus doesn't involve a check list. True discipleship requires interacting with Him constantly: remembering His teaching, listening for His direction, opening our eyes to where He is at work in our home and community. Remember, as Jesus meets us where we are, He shows us new ways to apply those truths as we follow Him.
subject: Fishing and Wishing
verse_text: Jesus said to Peter and Andrew, "Follow me and I will make you fishers of man."

*Today’s Verse:*

*Be kind to one another, tenderhearted, forgiving one another. *(Eph. 4:32)



*Today’s Reflection:*

What we should notice by this verse is that we should regard others more
important than ourselves. It seems public unkindness has become an
unpleasant and destructive trend, even with those who should be a

living example to our *nation.* Jesus is alive, and so is

His kindness, and it should live through each believer*.* *Show **someone
today that it is not hard to be a*

*better person.*

* Pastor Al *

Guide us, Lord, to be instruments of Your kindness in this world. Amen.

*Today’s Verse:*

*Blessed is that man who makes the Lord his trust and **does not respect
the proud, nor such as turn aside to **lies. *(Ps. 40:4) (read Ps. 40:1-4)

*Today’s Reflection:*

Deep down I know that each of us know that

earth is not our true home. One day Jesus will

lead us to our forever home. Until then, I’m learning the joy of being in
His presence. That’s where I feel most at home. *The next time you *

*feel unsettled, go to **Jesus in prayer. Ask Him *

*to help you feel at **home in Him.*

* Pastor Al *

*Today’s Verse:*

*You are of your father the devil, and the desires of your father y**ou
want to do. He was a murder from the beginning, and does **not stand in the
truth, because there is no truth in him. When **he speaks a lie, he speaks
from his own resources, for he is a **liar and the father of it. *(Jn. 8:44)




*Today’s Reflection:*

Whatever pops up, whether “good” of “bad,” we need

to pause, praise, and pray. We need to attend to whatever it is
without projecting
or jumping to conclusions, knowing Jesus goes with us wherever we go. I
admit it sometimes feels risky to not immediately brace for the worst, *but*
the peace I’ve gained through this practice

is priceless. *Whatever you face today, **bring it to *

*Jesus, giving thanks for the Holy Spirit's power to*

*never let you give up*

*Pastor Al *

Grant us the wisdom to attend to each situation without fear or anxiety, knowing that Your Holy Spirit will guide us and never let us give up. May we find refuge in Your love and the promise of Your eternal peace. Amen.

*Today’s Verse:*

*So I say to you, “Ask and it will be given to you; seek and you will **find;
knock and the door will be opened *

*to you *(Lk. 11:9)


*Today’s Reflection:*

My heart hurts whenever I picture those closed doors.

I think of Jesus letting us know that if we knock, He

will always open the door to us. I guess I’ve always imagined us knocking
to get in and Jesus opening the door to welcome us *inside.* But as I pray for
others, I now realize that sometimes when I knock, we’re the

ones who are inside, and we need Jesus to free us to come out and to let
others pour in. *Following Jesus *

*can mean opening **doors—literal and metaphorical—that create
isolation **between
ourselves and others.*

* Pastor Al*

Help us to recognize the doors that we have closed, whether intentionally or unintentionally, that have created barriers between ourselves and others. Give us the courage to open those doors, to welcome in those who need Your love and grace, and to go out and share Your light with a world that desperately needs it. May we always be willing to knock, and may You faithfully open the way for us to draw closer to You and to one another. Amen.

*Today’s Verse:*

*Fear not, for I have redeemed you; I have called you *

*by **your name. *(Isa. 43:1) *(NKJV)*



*Today’s Reflection:*

We are told that we need not fear, but still for some it still is a
constant companion. But if we are walking

with Jesus He has given us a new foundation on which

to stand. Paul says in 2 Cor. 5:17 (NIV) that if we are

in Christ, we are a “new creation.” Jesus gave us the power to step on “all
the power of the enemy without being hurt (Lk. 10:19), KJV, but the bigger
victory is

that our name is written in heaven. *So let us take heart that Jesus knows
our name and we **are His new creation. **He will help us overcome our
fears.*

* Pastor Al*

Help us to walk in the assurance of Your love and the security of our eternal home in heaven. May we find our strength in You, the one who has conquered all. Amen.

*Today’s Verse:*

*As Jesus was going down the road, He saw Matthew sitting **at his tax
collector booth. “Follow Me and be *

*My disciple,”**Jesus said to him. So, Matthew got up and followed Him. *(Mt.
9:9) *(NLT)*



*Today’s Reflection:*

Following religious rules doesn’t make us mature believers. It makes us
fearful of the consequences

for breaking them and judgmental toward those who

do not adhere to them. In contrast, following Jesus

places the emphases on a relationship with Him.

When that friendship becomes our focus, everything

else falls into place. *Here is the irony: being Jesus disciple **means we
follow rules designed to make *

*us better Christians.*

* Pastor Al *
original_reflection_text:
Following religious rules doesn’t make us mature believers. It makes us fearful of the consequences for breaking them and judgmental toward those who do not adhere to them. In contrast, following Jesus places the emphases on a relationship with Him. When that friendship becomes our focus, everything
else falls into place. Here is the irony: being Jesus disciple means we follow rules designed to make us better Christians.

prayer: Heavenly Father, we come before You with humble hearts, seeking to truly follow in the footsteps of Your Son, Jesus. Help us to move beyond a mere adherence to religious rules and regulations, and instead cultivate a deep, abiding relationship with You. May our focus be on walking closely with Christ, allowing His teachings to transform our lives from the inside out. Guide us, Lord, to die to ourselves and take up our cross, that we may truly become Your faithful disciples. In Jesus' name, Amen.

*Today’s Verse: *

*And we know that God causes everything to work together for **the good of
those who love God and*

* are called according to **His purpose for them. *

(Ro. 8:28)



*Today’s Reflection:*

The statement, *“For our good*,” does not mean that

all that happens to us is good. Evil is prevalent in

our fallen world, but God is able to turn every circumstance around for
our long-range good. Note

that God is not working to make us happy but to

fulfill His purpose. Note also this promise is not for

everybody. It can be claimed only by those who love

God and are called by Him, that is *those* whom the

Holy Spirit convinces to follow Christ. Such people

have a new perspective, a new mind set. They trust

in God, not in worldly treasures: their security is in heaven, not on
earth. Their faith in God does not

waver in pain or persecution because they know

God is with them, and are called according to God’s purpose.

*Pastor Al*

It can be claimed only by those who love God and are called by Him, that is those whom the
Holy Spirit convinces to follow Christ. Such people have a new perspective, a new mind set. They trust in God, not in worldly treasures: their security is in heaven, not on earth. Their faith in God does not waver in pain or persecution because they know God is with them, and are called according to God’s purpose.
original_verse_text: And we know that God causes everything to work together for the good of those who love God and are called according to His purpose for them.
prayer: Heavenly Father, we thank You that in all things, You work for the good of those who love You and are called according to Your purpose. Though we face trials and tribulations in this fallen world, we trust that You are with us, shaping us and molding us to fulfill Your eternal plan. Grant us the faith to endure, the wisdom to see Your hand at work, and the courage to proclaim Your goodness even in the midst of adversity. May our security be found in You alone, not in earthly treasures. We praise You, our Sovereign Lord. Amen.

The statement, “For our good,” does not mean that all that happens to us is good. Evil is prevalent in our fallen world, but God is able to turn every circumstance around for our long-range good. *Today’s Verse:*

*When the priests withdrew from the Holy Place, the cloud **filled the
temple of the Lord. And the priests*

*could not perform their service because of the cloud. *

*For the glory of the Lord **filled His temple.*

(1 Kings 8:10-11)

*Today’s Reflection:*

Like the priests of old, He’s called each of us to serve

in some way. But let us focus beyond those tangible tasks. Let’s leave room
for Jesus to interrupt and stop

us in our tracks. The glorious presence of the Lord is waiting to fill the
temple of our hearts. *Let’s pause *

*and ask Jesus to make us more **aware of His *

*presence.*

* Pastor Al*
original_reflection_text:
Like the priests of old, He’s called each of us to serve in some way.
But let us focus beyond those tangible tasks. Let’s leave room for Jesus to interrupt and stop us in our tracks. The glorious presence of the Lord is waiting to fill the temple of our hearts. Let’s pause and ask Jesus to make us more aware of His presence.

Help us to set aside our own agendas and make space for You to interrupt us, that we may be overwhelmed by the depth of Your love and the power of Your Spirit. May our lives be a living temple where Your glory dwells, that we may serve You with renewed purpose and passion. In the name of Jesus, we pray. Amen.

*Today’s Verse:*

*See, God has come to save me. I will trust in *

*Him and **not be afraid. The Lord God is my strength and my **song; He has
given me victory. *(Isa. 12:2)

*Today’s Reflection:*

Have you ever sensed the challenge of Jesus

to align your thoughts with the truth. *Do not *

*make an idol of **your daily rituals, *Jesus said.

*Today’s Verse:*

*A leper came to Him begging Him, and kneeling *

*he said to **Him, “If You choose, You can make me *

*clean.” Moved **with pity, Jesus stretched out His *

*hand and touched him, **and said to him, “I do *

*choose, be made whole.” *(Mk. 1:40-41)


*Today’s Reflection:*

As we follow Jesus through the Gospels, one thing

that we will notice is how Jesus spent His time. His calendar gives us a
clear picture of who He really

was. He was visited by shepherds. A man who eat locusts prepared the way
for His ministry, and His

best friends were smelly fishermen. For a greater

list read (Mt. 4:14). Now if Jesus is the embodiment

of God’s will on earth, then it’s clear what His will

is for us as His church, His people. *What **does *

*your schedule show your friends about who you*

*are? *

* Pastor Al*

from      : Pastor Sather <pastor.sather5@gmail.com>

*Today’s Verse:*

*In the world you will have tribulation; but be *

*of good **cheer, I have overcome the world. *

(Jn. 16:33)



*Today’s Reflection:*

*Do you ever find yourself* uncertain of how to

console someone who is going through a difficult

time? Questions keep swirling through my head

when I am talking to a friend who needs consoling.

I feel compelled to mention a verse or two, because

it is the desire of Jesus to comfort. When Jesus was

surrounded by masses of hurting people, He had

compassion for them. Jesus tells us to “be of good

cheer” even when facing turbulent times. Whether

we are comforting people who share our faith or

others—who are struggling, we should put them,

in remembrance of the sweet, tender words of

Jesus that are able to sustain us when we are hurting.

*Pastor Al*

subject   : Subject: ALWAYS CALL ON THE GREAT PHYSICIAN (1-24-2020)

*Today’s Verse:*

*He took our sickness and removed our diseases. *

(Mt. 8:17)



*Today’s Reflection:*

There are times when the answers to my prayers don’t

come as quickly as I want them to, but it still surprises

me when I experience instant relief from Jesus. The

N.T. is filled with stories of how Jesus showed compassion to those who
were suffering, and often

they received their healing immediately. Whatever

the circumstances you should remember Jesus cares

for all of us—men, women, young, old, privileged,

and underprivileged. Jesus was crucified on the cross

for the forgiveness of our sins and the healing of our sicknesses and
diseases. In faith we can cry out to Him

and expect His healing touch. The pain may be gone

right away as it has happened to me at various times,

or the healing may come much latter. But one thing is

certain, Jesus is always concerned with our well-being.

*Pastor Al*

*Subject: BEING LIKE MINDED *(1-25-2020)



*Today’s Verse:*

*Again I say unto you, that if two of you shall agree*

*on earth as touching any thing that they shall ask, *

*it** shall be done for them of my Father which is in*

*heaven. *(Mt. 18:19)



*Today’s Reflection:*

Jesus says that if two or three of us agree in prayer,

His Father will do what we ask. Prayer is an invitation

to see His at work in amazing ways. When we pray together, our prayers will
usher in His presence. *If *

*you need a miracle today, find **a* p*rayer partner.*

* Pastor Al*

*Today’s Verse:*

*When you pray, do not use vain repetitions as the heathens *do. For They
think that they will be heard

for their many words. (Mt. 6:7)

*Today’s Reflections:*

Repeating the same words over and over like a magic

incantation is no way to ensure that God will hear your

prayer. It’s not wrong to come to God many times with

your requests—Jesus encourages persistent prayer. *But*

He condemns the shallow repetition of words that are

not offered with a sincere heart. We can never pray to

much if our prayers are honest and sincere. *Before you*

*start to pray, make sure you mean what you say. *

* Pastor Al*

May our prayers be a reflection of our trust in Your perfect will and our dependence on Your gracious provision. Guide us to pray persistently, yet with reverence and faith, knowing that You hear the cries of Your children. In Jesus' name, Amen.

*Today (*1-27-2020) *Verse:*

*Let nothing be done through selfish ambition or *

*conceit, but** in lowliness of mind let each esteem *

*others better than himself. * (Phil. 2:3)



*Today’s Reflection:*

*Selfishness can ruin a church, but genuine humility *

*can **build it. Being humble involves having a true perspective **about
ourselves**. *(see Ro. 12:3) *It does *

*not mean that we **should put ourselves down. Before God, we are
sinners, **saved
only by God’s grace, but *

*we are saved and therefore **have great worth in God’s Kingdom. We are to
lay aside **selfishness and treat *

*others with respect and common **courtesy. *

*When we consider the interests of others more*

*important **then ours it** links us with Christ, who*

* was a true example of **humility.*

* Pastor Al *

When we consider the interests of others more important then ours it links us with Christ, who was a true example of humility.

May we consider the interests of others as more important than our own, that we may be united in Your Kingdom and glorify Your name. Amen.

*Today’s Verse*

*This is the confidence we have in approaching God; *

*that **If we ask anything according to His will, He *

*hears us. *(I Jn. 5:14)



*Today’s Reflection:*

Other places in Scripture, we also see that God

assures us that He will conform us to Christ’s

likeness. And I believe He will. Our cooperation

hastens this lifelong process. I also believe that

as we mature, our prayers more closely align with

Jesus’s heart, and our eyes are more attuned to how

He works. As years go by I’ve become more con-

vinced, though, sometimes through very painful

lessons, that Jesus’s way is always best, so I’m

more submissive to the stream of His will.

*When I pray and receive, I trust He has been *

*listening and answers.*

*Pastor Al*

In Jesus' name, Amen.

*Today’s Verse:*

*“For my thoughts are not your thoughts. Nor *

*are your **ways my ways,” says the Lord. *(Isa 55:8)



*Today’s Reflection:*

The people of Israel were *foolish *to act as if they knew what God was
thinking and planning. His knowledge and wisdom are far greater than any
human’s. We are *foolish* also to think we can fit God into our mold—to make
His plans and purposes conform to ours. Instead, we must strive

to fit into His plans. *The Lord always **extends *

*an **invitation to us for His salvation.*

* Pastor Al*
original_reflection_text: The people of Israel were foolish to act as if they knew what God was thinking and planning. His knowledge and wisdom are far greater than any human’s. We are foolish also to think we can fit God into our mold—to make His plans and purposes conform to ours. Instead, we must strive to fit into His plans. The Lord always extends an invitation to us for His salvation.

prayer: Heavenly Father, we humbly acknowledge that Your thoughts and ways are far beyond our understanding. Your wisdom and knowledge are unsearchable, and we are but finite beings. Forgive us for the times we have tried to make Your plans fit our own, rather than submitting to Your perfect will. Lord, we open our hearts to receive the invitation of Your salvation, trusting that Your ways are higher and better than our own. May we ever seek to align our lives with Your purposes. Amen.

We are foolish also to think we can fit God into our mold—to make His plans and purposes conform to ours. Instead, we must strive to fit into His plans. The Lord always extends an invitation to us for His salvation.

subject   : Subject: A STRENGTHENING SUPPORT (1-30-2020)
from      : Pastor Sather <pastor.sather5@gmail.com>

*Today’s Verse:*

*I can do all things through Christ who strengthens *

*me. *(Phil. 4:13)



*Today’s Reflection:*

Sometimes what a verse doesn’t say is just as important as what the verse
says. I was recently reminded that while I can do all things through Jesus,
He never said

I had to do it all. I’m the one who puts the pressure on myself. Sometimes
the thing He wants to give m*e is* strength for speaking that powerful
little word, “No.”

Jesus wants us to get our value from Him. Not from doing all things. But
from resting in His love for us

and letting His strength shine through our weakness.

But how can we do that if we never admit we have a weakness? *What’s t**he
hardest thing you have to do today?*

* Pastor Al*

Give us the courage to speak that difficult word "no" when needed, that we may rest in Your perfect peace. May Your strength shine through our weaknesses, for it is in You that we can do all things. Amen.

*Today’s Verse:*

*Many of the disciples said, “This is very hard to understand.*

*How can anyone accept it?” Jesus was aware that His *

*disciples **were complaining, so He said to them, “Does this offend you?”**At
this point many of His disciples turned away and deserted **Him. *(Jn.
6:60—61, 66)



*Today’s Reflection:*

Offending others when standing for the truth is inevitable. We

can’t control how others receive our words, but we can control

the manner in which we present them. Jesus never stooped to

name calling, or verbally tearing apart the character of anyone

who disagreed with Him. Neither should we. *Our **role is to *

*follow His example and trust His Holy Spirit to **change the *

*hearts of those who take offense. *

* Pastor Al*

original_subject: PRAYING FOR A CHANGE OF HEARTS
original_verse_text: 60 On hearing it, many of his disciples said, “This is a hard teaching. Who can accept it?” 61 Aware that his disciples were grumbling about this, Jesus said to them, “Does this offend you? 62 Then what if you see the Son of Man ascend to where he was before! 63 The Spirit gives life; the flesh counts for nothing. The words I have spoken to you-they are full of the Spirit and life. 64 Yet there are some of you who do not believe.” For Jesus had known from the beginning which of them did not believe and who would betray him. 65 He went on to say, “This is why I told you that no one can come to me unless the Father has enabled them.” 66 From this time many of his disciples turned back and no longer followed him.
prayer: Heavenly Father, we come before You, seeking wisdom and discernment as we navigate the challenges of standing firm in Your truth. Help us, like Your Son, to speak with grace and compassion, even when faced with opposition. May our words be seasoned with salt, reflecting the love and patience of Christ. Give us the courage to stand for what is right, while also extending understanding and kindness to those who may be offended. We trust in Your power to transform hearts and minds, for Your glory alone. Amen.
reflection: Offending others when standing for the truth is inevitable. We can’t control how others receive our words, but we can control the manner in which we present them. Jesus never stooped to name calling, or verbally tearing apart the character of anyone who disagreed with Him. Neither should we. Our role is to follow His example and trust His Holy Spirit to change the hearts of those who take offense.
